reviewText: This movie is an amalgamation of poor decisions and poor understanding. Remember being young and having to constantly correct your parents whenever they attempted to discuss the cartoons and video games you liked? That's this movie. It's as if Shyamalan walked in on his son watching Avatar, watched one episode with him, and decided to make a movie adaptation as a surprise birthday present.Where to begin? First of all, the deliberate decision to pronounce many of the characters' names differently from the cartoon reeks of ignorance. What does this accomplish? It serves only to instantly throw off and alienate the real fans of the show, and in no way enhances the movie for people not in the know.Second, pacing. This movie ludicrously attempts to condense an entire season consisting of roughly 7 and a half hours of content into 90 minutes. A feat so daunting Shyamalan probably knew it was impossible, but did it anyway! I had watched the 1st season of the show directly before watching this movie and was amazed at how fast the it tries to plow through the storyline of the show. The film is so rushed it offers no time to introduce its characters. Characters that once formed an ensemble are now given the back burner in favor of the main character.Finally, the magic of the show is just simply lost in the transition to live action. I don't know if the fighting in the cartoon can be pulled off in this medium, but the movie seems to want me to believe that it can't. The iconic regalia of the fire nation in the cartoon just comes off as drab in the film. Just like Dragonball Evolution, the film not only brings absolutely nothing new to the table of the source material, but taints it for merely existing.

reviewText: My little sister and I went to see The Last Airbender when it came out in theaters this summer. We're both huge fans of the animated series.  When I heard that this movie was coming out, I was a little worried, but I decided to have an open mind and ended up being really excited about it.Unfortunately, my original instincts were correct. This is a terrible movie. What's really awful about it is the complete lack of regard Shyamalan obviously has for Avatar: The Last Airbender.  He said in an interview that fans of the animated series would notice that the movie's spirit was identical to the spirit of the show. Ha! He obviously didn't watch the show very closely, if that's what he thinks.For me the biggest problems in the movie are with the characters and the lack of humor.  Why is Aang so serious all the time? What got me hooked on the show was how even though he has a this huge, imposing destiny, Aang is still a kid.  He plays pranks, he jokes around, and he takes detours on their journey to ride giant fish.  The movie also totally skips over Aang's crush on Katara.  Katara acts as the mature voice of reason in the movie the few times we see her doing anything, but there's no sibling banter with Sokka whatsoever. She also isn't shown improving her waterbending. In Book 1 of the series, Katara goes from a beginning waterbender to a master by the end of the season. Movie-Sokka is much to serious. He provided so much comic relief in the show, and I have a hard time seeing what his purpose is in this movie.  And the worst part about the characters is that they have no relationship with each other.  You never get to see a friendship building between Aang, Katara, and Sokka. They just seem to be three kids randomly traveling together.  Sokka and Katara say a couple of times that "Aang is their responsibility," not that they care about him at all.  The interaction between the three main characters and the growth of their relationship is a great and integral part of the series. In the movie I don't even think they like each other.As for humor, this is a kid's movie! Even though the story is epic, there should be light hearted moments. Harry Potter and The Chronicles of Narnia have both managed that, even more grown up movies like Lord of the Rings are still funny, but Airbender just didn't have it.  The only time my sister and I laughed during this movie was at the ridiculous water tribe battle cry. "Oooooooo!" And I'm pretty sure that wasn't meant to be humorous. (And by the way, my sister is 10 and usually loves any movie that she sees, and she pretty much hates this movie. So apparently Shyamalan made this movie to stupid for even sweet, open-minded kids, his target audience)As for the changing of the names, I was willing to let that slide if the movie was good, but since it wasn't hearing Ohng and Sohkka really annoyed me.  It takes a lot of nerve to tell someone that they are pronouncing names that they created incorrectly. None of these names (Aang, Katara, Sokka, Iroh) are actual names, but Shyamalan felt the need to insult Avatar's creators by saying that he needed to fix their made up world.Skip this movie. Watch the animated series.
summary: I really wanted to like this movie...

reviewText: M.Night Shyamalan used to give us kick-ass mind-benders (like Sixth Sense and Un-Breakable), the kind of movie which makes viewers gasp towards the end because a final revelation forces them to rethink the entire movie retroactively. Bruce Willis' character's sudden realisation that he was dead was a milestone in cinema history, a plot-device that ended being copied in other big movies (the one which jumps out strongest is Nicole Kidman's The Others). This was followed by less shocking though still appreciated twist-and-turn movies like Un-Breakable (another Willis hit), Signs and even The Village, though here there were already signs (pun yes) that Shyamalan's craft was going to require a heavy injection of something new (the Eureka index was definitely falling), failing which he'd just be the guy who made movies where the camera has a tendency of lingering and the characters spend eons talking to each other (another such director is Clint Eastwood).So what happened? Was the lure of CGI box-office collections too strong, so strong that story-telling-and-making is thrown to the, err, air? Because other than the fancy shots of the elements being manipulated and used as weapons, I'm not sure what else is new/good/worthwhile about the Last Air-Bender.The acting is second- (even third-)rate; other than Prince Zuko's uncle, the rest look like they're auditioning for the high-school end of year play. The plot is predictable and is so loop-holed you'd think someone threw some fireballs at it. The 'spirituality'? Don't even get me started.(In one scene, the Avatar - supposedly the incarnation of the source of harmony in the world, the One who can 'bend' all the four elements - asks, "Do you have a spiritual place where I can meditate?" - and I wanted to go, "Down the hall, turn left, first door on the right. Please flush when you're done.")And, most disappointly of all, I repeat: There is no mind-twirling twist here. There is no unanticipated near-the-end scene which brings surprise and coherency to the whole movie. The Last Air-Bender, in a word, is nothing more than a PG-13 CGI-soaked version of something Jean-Claude Van Damme did when he was two decades younger. Something which draws the crowd but it utterly forgettable; one can hardly imagine having anything resembling an 'intelligent conversation' about the movie (or at least the kind inspired by gems like Sixth Sense). To risk a judgment harsh yet unfortunately true: With this movie, Shyamalan has lost his defining charateristic. Why, pray tell, bother getting him to direct it?We need a return to great story-telling with profound themes. This year only Inception has come close, IMO. The Air-Bender? If I could hurl flames at the screen at the end of the show I might've tried. Alas, I can only bend pop-corn.

reviewText: Before I bash this movie with a metal-encrusted Toph (and I will) there are some things that really ought to be pointed out, by an adult fan of the actual TV show.Number 1.THE CREATORS OF THE SHOW ARE AMONG THE PRODUCERS OF THE LAST AIRBENDER. You can see it on the case, you can see it in the credits. They were very much involved in the decision to let 'Shame-a-lan' handle the writing for this movie. Yes, it was a mistake. But they were there. M. Night did not slip this under the original creators somehow.Number 2.THIS HAS 3D APPA AND 3D MOMO IN IT!! And they are wonderful. Seeing those two things alone made it worth my twenty dollars. I loved them!Number 3.THE EFFECTS WERE NOT 'BAD'. They were simply inappropriately used for what they should have been trying to accomplish. But again, the creators were there. They could have stopped this, and they did not.Number 4.THIS IS JUST A MOVIE. Yes, I know that is very disappointing! I love the show, and I know that it is more than just a show, and we all would have hoped this would be more than just a movie, which it is not. But let's face it guys, it's just mediocre. It didn't make you cry blood, it didn't make worlds end.--------That all being said... BASH THIS MOVIE WITH METAL-ENCASED TOPH.Did the filmmakers EVER watch the show? Who the hell are Ung, Soak-uh, and ee-row. It was AAng SOKKa and I-roh.Avatar: The Last Airbender was not really an action show. It was more of a fantasy-drama hybrid. It was enchanting and heartwarming... and in terms of that, this movie is just stupid. Sokka is only passively funny, he will not make you laugh out loud like he does in the show. Aang (Or 'Ung' as some apparently prefer) has no energy whatsoever and doesn't even ride around on his little bubble things. Zuko's scar looks like stretch marks -- it is far from the 'who's bad?' disfiguring ear-growth-stunting thing across his face that was in the show, and you can't feel nearly as bad for him and you just kind of don't care about him. He is just kind of a bad guy who seems like he will always be a bad guy -- static and closed minded. Which is not how he was in the show at all, he was very doubtful and torn, and quite frankly, really interesting, even when he was still being evil and whiny. The Firelord was not some pompous doughboy looking guy either, he was buff and aggressive and the anime equivalent of 'sexy', for lack of a better term. In this movie he is also lame. Azula is still fun, but you only see her for about two seconds at a time.Better watch out for that 'Acne Key', it's gonna getcha!Shame-a-lan should not have written this. He SUCKED SO MUCH. If the writing had been done well, this would have been an amazing movie. His actual directing was really not so bad, as some people are having fun saying. His writing is what sucked, and someone should have stopped him. But they didn't! We just have to accept that.Yes, it sucked. It sucked it sucked it sucked. TOPH SMASH!!But... you have to own it. You just do. It's The Last Airbender. Just shut up and watch it! Pretend M. Night Shamedusall isn't there, and just watch it.

reviewText: Let's take a moment to discuss something completely different, but entirely relevant to The Last Airbender. The trend of the new first Neon Genesis Evangelion movie versus the Cowboy Bebop movie. These are anime, which is a style that inspired the Nickelodeon animated show.The Evangelion movie is a retelling of the original show's first few episodes. It's supposed to bring a wider audience to the franchise and eventually retell the whole story in a condensed manner. It is supposed to do so through a trilogy of movies. This is pretty much exactly how The Last Airbender is being set up.The Cowboy Bebop movie retells nothing. It is a standalone movie that takes place in continuity between two of the latter episodes of the series.Let's look at this a little closer. For the Evangelion movie, since they're retelling the story, what is the incentive for the audience to expand their horizon by watching the original show now? What do the fans of the show gain by seeing the same stuff, only mutilated to fit the compressed time of a motion picture?Would it not have been better to have followed in the footsteps of Cowboy Bebop, and told an original story that took place somewhere between a couple episodes of the show? This may have screwed up continuity a bit, but better a tiny bit of fan hatred than almost universal hatred period. Also, what was gained by having a live action adaptation? Where does that make sense? What other animated show has successfully been adapted to live action? The first Ninja Turtles movie is the only one that comes to mind. Why was this not animated? The art and style of the television show was amazing, the bending of each nation had a specific influence in real, distinct styles of martial arts, and it's like they just said screw everything about the show except the most superficial stuff that we can make with CG, toss in some bad redesigns, horrible (but typical of M. Night Shamamalam) dialogue, and hope for a return on investment. Unacceptable to the fans of the show, unacceptable to the franchise and to the people who put so much effort into the original show, and generally just insulting to the creative process as a whole.And speaking of M. Night Shamuamalm, whose decision was it to give an action movie to a man known for slow-burn, pretentious, narcissistic bad movies that lack humor, emotion, action, realistic actions, reactions and dialogue of people, or color; all the things the original show has in spades. Who thought this was a match made in heaven? Don't let them ever make decisions about movies again. Stop that. Don't do that.Y'know, this movie's going to be somewhere between $17 and $30. Your money is better spent on the first season of the original show. It's far better value for money, in that it is longer (20-some shows at 22-ish minutes each), it's far more entertaining, funny, cohesive, imaginative, and involving than this movie could ever hope to be.Here, I'll make is easy for you:Avatar The Last Airbender - The Complete Book 1 CollectionAnd if you want to go a step further, here's the collector's edition:Avatar The Last Airbender: The Complete Book 1 (Collector's Edition)

reviewText: This film is based off of the show Avatar: The Last Airbender, Book 1: Water.  The way they rushed the scenes and script, one might've thought they'd get through the complete series!  Die hard fans of the show will not like this film.  The cast that seemed to be drawn from a hat were weak, but to be half fair, the script was an epic fail.  The special effects were equal to that of a cheap network sci-fi show.  And as far as directing goes--I cringed about 2 years ago after hearing rumors about M. Night Shyamalan being this film's director, and still, after seeing it, I cringe.  Kudos to The Sixth Sense, but nothing else.If you haven't seen the Nickelodeon series, I highly suggest you do.  You're sure to find it on Netflix or your local Blockbuster.  There are 3 books in this series--Book 1: Water, Book 2: Earth, Book 3: Fire--with each book containing 4 to 5 volumes. As mentioned before, this film starts off with Book 1: Water.  You learn more from Katara's introduction monologue in the opening cartoon episode than you do from most of the feature film.  The series introduction is far more simple to understand.Obviously, you cannot possibly cram every detail from the series into an hour and a half long film.  But this wasn't a film based off of the whole series.  It's based off the grand opening of the series!  So there should be time to develop Aang's crazy fun and playful, carefree character.  There should be time for Sokka to crack some of his obvious, lame jokes that only he finds funny.  There should be time to show the motherly and strong side Katara had since losing her mother.  And it should probably have shown the true, brutal and ruthless nature of the Fire Nation, with exception to banished Prince Zuko's uncle, General Iroh, who's quite lighthearted and wise.  But it's as if these things were not important, so we're left with a flat cast rambling from a shoddy script.  It's as if no one who participated in the making of the film actually watched the series.  It was put together like a school project.So overall, as a film by itself, the film was poor.  Had I not seen the series, I probably would've given it 2 stars because I think the ideas of controlling the 4 elements and visiting the Spirit World are cool.  But still--poorly cast, poorly directed, cheap special effects, and a horrendously written script.  If you found this film at all interesting, you'll be a million times more entertained watching the Nickelodeon cartoon series.

reviewText: Many of the reviews have stated exactly what went wrong with this film, so I will not repeat them here, but I will say that everything that I adored in the cartoon series is completely gone from the film, and I mean everything. Yes, I realize that many things had to be left out in order to squeeze an entire season into one movie, however, a few SIMPLE things such as character name pronunciation and accurate character representation would have made the film less painful to watch. As a person who occasionally gets teary-eyed during the more emotional sequences of the cartoon series, I felt absolutely no emotion (other than anger) while watching this movie. The actors playing the characters were about as fun to watch as seeing paint dry. I am appalled that a 400-plus minute season of a show could possibly be crammed into a movie that was barely 1 and 1/2 hours. My husband and I were both bored to death while watching this, but we really love the cartoon series, and we are glad that we rented this at Redbox for $1.00, which, as another reviewer stated, is too high a price. The only things that were worth seeing in live action were the costumes (however inaccurate they were), and the sets. Bending was sufficient, but we would have liked to have seen more of it. I would rate this ZERO stars if I could, but the cartoon series is definitely a 5-star in my book.

reviewText: First let me say that I have not yet seen the original cartoon this is based on, it is on my to do list but as of writing this I can not compare the two. Ok now I heard allot of bad things about this movie, but when I sat down with my hubby last night to watch it I was pleasantly surprised, I found the movie entertaining and while it had quite a few flaws and is not what i would call a really good movie, I think it provided a fun watch. Now The Lat Airbender is set in an Asian inspired fantasy world where there are four kingdoms, one for each of the four Western elements, now a few people in each kingdom can manipulate their birth element and are called benders. Now the Fire realm have gone to war on everyone else and have among other things killed off every airbender, now the people's only hope come in the form of a legend that a character called the avatar, someone able to bend all elements will come and save them. Off course this prophecy comes true in the first five minutes of the movie and the rest of the film follows said avatar and two children, a waterbender and her brother who helps him, around on their adventure to liberate the world.Now this movie follows about every fantasy stereotype they can find, however the storyline is interesting enough to hold your attention. Some of the fights in this movie look just plain dumb, but some of the magic battles with elements at least look good. Most of the adult actors do a good job, but the child actors is a different story, Noah Ringer as Aang do a passable job, Dev Patel as Prince Zuko is rather good but the other child actors is lackluster and just seams to be delivering lines.The Last Airbender would have been a better film if it had been longer, characters do not get enough time to develop, however this is a problem many reviews talk about and I do not agree that the story is so condensed as to make the movie unwatchable, however the phasing do seam odd. One thing that I do find disturbing in the movie however is that all the Fire Nation characters have Arabic appearance, I guess following the Asian theme they are supposed to be Indian, however they sure look Arabic to me, now I am all for artistic freedoms however I do question the wisdom of having every villain look Arabic in our current political climate.All in all I found The Last Airbender to be a average film, not so bad as many say, quite entertaining and it do have good parts like the creature designs and some of the music which is quite nice. However phasing problem, lack of involvement from the child actors, very up and down quality to the computer graphics along with other problems keep the movie from being really good. However I was entertained by it and I think that if someone like fantasy, and especially if they are kids themselves they they might at least enjoy this film for a rent. I came to this film with zero expectations and I was pleasantly surprised.

reviewText: I'd heard nothing but bad things about The Last Airbender over the last couple of months. Most of it was feedback from fans of the animated series, who went off about tons of changes made to characters, no matter how minor they were. Ethnicity, pronunciations of names, the color of their outfits, everything. I have only seen a few episodes of the Avatar series, and liked what I saw, but never had the time to watch it in its entirety, so more or less, I went into this not knowing anything about the source material. At the same time, M. Night Shyamalan sure hasn't had any good movies under his belt for the last 6-7 years, so I was already doubtful. Well, I thought I had my picks for the worst movies I'd seen all year, but watching The Last Airbender, I might have to reorganize my list, because this sure as hell is in the top 3. Again, this is not a review from a fan of the series, so there isn't any bias. But this -is- pretty awful, and knowing that they tried to cram 20 episodes of the series into one movie just makes me wonder what they were thinking releasing the movie as it was.The basic plot summary is that there's a boy named Aang, more or less a messiah who has been missing from the world for a century. There are four different tribes on earth, each controlling one of the main elements: earth, fire, wind and water (sorry Captain Planet fans, no Heart here) and Aang was born with the ability to control all four. It's his job to keep the peace amongst them, but things aren't going too well, thanks to the Fire nation trying to take over the other tribes. Aang and two waterbenders go with Aang to try and keep the Fire nation from taking over everything. Yes, it's as boring as it sounds.Normally when I do a plot summary for a movie, it's a lot longer than that. But with The Last Airbender, I was so bored watching the movie that I didn't care about anything. None of the characters appealed to me because of how poor the performances were, and everyone seemed devoid of emotion half the time. Any potentially cool action scenes were lost in slow fights of elements almost to the point where it seemed like there was lag when someone would throw fire or water at someone. Really, if it takes 2 seconds for your fireball to merely be summoned, and a few more long seconds to reach the target who's no more than 20 feet in front of you, what's the point in using it at all? Something else that bugged me about the elemental powers here is that the Fire nation is seen as a huge threat, conquering other territories, and many are scared of them. Yet when they get into fights with earth and water users, nearly all fire attacks are blocked because water puts it out and earth just plain stops it. 'reminds me of Pokemon games and how screwed you are most of the time in early gym battles if you pick a fire type as your starter. What I'm guessing are lovable animal characters in the animated series are lifeless special effects in the movie- a giant flying buffalo-looking thing, and a little flying monkey. The little monkey was used so much that you'd think the animation team was desperate to get it in any scene they possibly could. I'm really surprised I managed to stay awake through the whole movie, even with the 'epic' final battle that lasted a few minutes and had no climax to speak of. You know what? I think watching this movie has inspired me to give the animated series a shot now, because there's no way that thing can be as lifeless as this junk.And yet, I'll bump up the rating by a star because of the blu-ray, which looks and sounds incredible. This would be a great movie to show off your home theater with, provided people don't know what movie it is you're showing them. Visually, it looks perfect, and the DTS-HD MA 5.1 lossless audio track is great. The special features are pretty loaded too, with an hour long documentary going over everything that went into the movie, a featurette just for creating the final battle, and more. It's just too bad such a boring movie got better treatment than movies that are at least average.The Last Airbender is one of those movies that I'll forget about in a week or two from now, but always remember as one of the worst I saw in 2010. It's definitely not one of the 10 worst movies I've ever seen, but I can't stress how boring it is. How do you make an animated series about martial arts, element controlling, and interesting looking creatures, and turn it into...THIS? Most of M. Night's movies have a twist near the end, but I think the twist with The Last Airbender is that it never gets good. Stay away unless you're wondering what it is that everyone's complaining about.

reviewText: Let me start this review off by saying that The Last Airbender was an embarassing piece of filmmaking. I could not see how the filmmakers saw the supposed finished product of this and thought it was okay to be released. I think M. Night Shyamalan is a talented director, but only in his element (no pun intended), which is obviously horror and contemporary science fiction. Going into the realm of fantasy and action was not an intelligent move for Shyamalan. I was strongly anticipating this film, and I was actually looking forward to see Shyamalan take on a completely new project, which I heard he was very passionate about. So, it had to be good, right? No way! The film was sloppy--an utter mess--the characters were extremely one-dimensional (I could care less for the fate of any of them). The only thing that got me through this film were some of the action sequences, which were, at times, impressive to behold, but they did not deliver quite as well as they should have. For one thing, there was always a set choreography in the art of bending, which was very aesthetically pleasing, but that never quite worked in tandem with the special effects. Another aspect of the film that butchered the overall aesthetic was the cinematography: it was never stable. I felt M. Night Shyamalan did not know what he wanted to do with the camera, or what he wanted to focus on. In other words, the camerawork was drab and quite awkward. For example, sometimes he'd have a long shot depicting two of the actors. He'd have one actor acting while the other literally blatantly seems to be waiting to deliver his lines. If the blocking is off, there are ways of concealing that. For example, instead of showing the two actors, show a close-up of the one communicating and then a close-up of the other actor responding. But no, Shyamalan was too fond of his long and medium shots without bothering to block secondary characters that were in the frame. Other shots were so close that when the lead would talk, his mouth would disappear under the frame. That is bad filmmaking. I felt Shyamalan was trying to apply some of the camerawork he used in films such as Unbreakable or Signs, but that kind of cinematography is too mundane for a child's fantasy film. Both Unbreakable and Signs were meant to embrace a sense of realism. The Last Airbender destroys the conventions of realism and it should be acknowledged and treated as such. For example, a director of photography such as Bruno Delbonel would have been able to treat this material like a work of art. If this film at least had good camerawork, I think that would have distracted me away from the daft plot, acting, and script discrepancies. I know Shyamalan wishes to make a series out of this, just like the show. I don't think he should give up on it, but I do think he should read a lot of the reviews for this film and try to enhance the story for the next installment. EIther he do that, or step down as director and become producer, and allow another person take the creative, artistic licenses with this material. Many have said this film marks the end of Shyamalan's career, and I say I definitely disagree. Many filmmakers hit rough patches in movie-making careers, and Shyamalan has hit one. I think he needs to return to the genre that has made him famous and begin casting A-list actors in his films again, because a lot of the reasons his latest films have been so bad is because of his casting decisions. He set the bar high with The Sixth Sense, and I think he can make a comeback. Hey, who knows, he might nail the sequel and regain his reputation again. Let's hope so.
summary: Wow! Sloppy Film for a very Entertaining and Visually Stunning Show!

reviewText: Ever since seeing "The Sixth Sense," my nature has been to resist the films of M. Night Shyamalan. I have to admit that now. I'm aware of his technical skills and his ability to build tension, and yet something within me finds his work profoundly unappealing. I go in with an open mind, but then, minute by minute, it seems as if he's purposely trying to push me away with his unreasonably slow pacing, his amateurish dialogue, his bizarre character development, his ill-fitting sense of humor, and in some cases, his ridiculous plot twists. By the time I leave, a wall has gone up, and I feel cheated and angry. Many have felt the same way about "Lady in the Water" and "The Happening," but few agreed with me on "The Sixth Sense," "Unbreakable," "Signs," and "The Village." The first even garnered an Oscar nomination for Best Picture.Now we have "The Last Airbender," a live-action 3-D adaptation of the Nickelodeon anime series "Avatar: The Last Airbender." Unfortunately, Shyamalan has proven he can alienate younger audiences just as easily as older ones. It's a children's film, and yet he didn't seem to have children in mind when making it; it's unmanageably plot-heavy, the dialogue is rife with incomprehensible exposition, the last minute 2-D to 3-D conversion is unimpressive, and worst of all, the characters are badly drawn - a mistake, I suspect, that was made worse with the casting of white actors in roles that were intended to be Asian and Inuit. There are a few enjoyable action sequences and moments of digital wizardry, but on the whole, I cannot envision anyone, kids least of all, making heads or tails of this film.The premise is that, in an alternate reality, the world is divided into four elemental kingdoms: Air, Water, Earth, and Fire. Within each are people who can manipulate, or bend, the elements. The Fire Nation, having already overseen the genocide of the Air Nomads, is now waging war against the Earth Kingdom and the Water Tribes. From the Southern Water Tribe, we meet a teen waterbender named Katara (Nicola Peltz) and her brother, Sokka (Jackson Rathbone); while hunting, they crack open a gigantic sphere of ice, releasing little Aang (Noah Ringer), the sole surviving airbender who disappeared 100 years ago. As it turns out, he's also the Avatar, which is to say he's the only one with the ability to control all four elements. Apparently, he can go into meditative trances and have conversations with a dragon spirit, a skill that's never adequately explained apart from its obvious implications.While well skilled in the art of airbending, Aang was never trained to bend water, earth, or fire. So begins his journey to the Northern Water Tribe, since, according to him, water training the natural progression from air training. He has to be careful; the Fire Nation is aware of his existence, and more than one person is pursuing him. Firstly, there's Fire Lord Ozai (Cliff Curtis). Secondly, there's Ozai's exiled son, Prince Zuko (Dev Patel), who hopes to regain his honor by capturing Aang. Finally, there's Admiral Zhao (Aasif Mandvi), Zuko's main rival.It seems basic enough, but the plot is deceptively weighty, mostly due to extremely long-winded explanations about various spirits, periods in history, peoples, places, and philosophies. Some are woven into unnecessary subplots. When Aang, Katara, and Sokka arrive in the Northern Water Tribe, for example, Sokka immediately falls in love a white-haired princess named Yue (Seychelle Gabriel); because so little time is spent on them, we can't invest in their relationship, nor can we absorb the details of her miraculous birth or her connection to the spirit of the moon. And then there's Zuko's uncle, Iroh (Shaun Toub), who really serves no purpose except to be an easy-going crutch for Zuko to lean on. He has his own troubled past, although it's alluded to so casually and briefly that one wonders why Shyamalan deemed it necessary.What he seems to be doing is taking an entire series' worth of information and packing it into a single film. This isn't how it works; when it comes to a film adaptation, especially of a lengthy source, one must know exactly which story should be told and then proceed to remove the extraneous details. Yes, sacrifices would be made, but the simple fact is that movies generally require streamlines plots. There's no conceivable way audiences are going to take in everything "The Last Airbender" tells them. There's simply too much of it. Worse still, it's not told particularly well. If you doubt me, listen to the dialogue Shyamalan supplies Aang with. When he speaks, he sounds more like a modern-day kid than a revered figure of myth.I don't want to write Shyamalan off as a bad filmmaker. He has disappointed me time and time again, but I can't help but feel that, somewhere deep down, he has what it takes to make a good movie. His previous films, even the ones I flat out hated, all had flashes of greatness. What he needs to finally realize is that successful films cannot be just about the craft; he must stop laboring over atmosphere and put some effort into actual storytelling. "The Last Airbender," while stylistically and thematically different from his earlier efforts, is a burden to watch, an overstuffed and underdeveloped adventure fantasy that doesn't have any audience capable of following along in mind. Yet again, I have built up a wall, and its seeming less and less likely that I'll ever be able to knock it down.

reviewText: THE LAST AIRBENDERSTARRING: Noah Ringer, Dev Patel, Nicola Peltz, Jackson Rathbone, Shaun Toub, Aasif Mandvi, Seychelle Gabriel and Cliff CurtisWRITTEN BY: M. Night ShyamalanDIRECTED BY: M. Night ShyamalanRated: PGGenre: Action / FantasyRelease Date: 01 July 2010Review Date: 22 September 2010M. Night Shyamalan is a long, long ways away from The Sixth Sense and Signs. Between what he did with the second half of The Happening, and what he's done here with The Last Airbender - I'm in no rush to see his next film. And don't even get me started on The Village; I'd run out of ink and you'd go blind.Noah Ringer stars as Aang; `the last Airbender.' What the hell is an Airbender you ask? Someone who can bend air. Why would someone want to bend air? To swoosh away bad guys, I guess - you tell me. Am I the only one that finds this incredibly lame? There really is no better word than lame, I promise.The movie is filled with characters that can bend things. Earth, fire, water and air. There are never-ending segments of watching characters interact with one another, using their different bending techniques on each other. How is this entertaining? The special effects add little to no appeal to this boring plot point.Brother and sister Sokka (Jackson Rathbone) and Katara (Nicola Peltz) find Aang early on in the film and feel a need to protect him. They need to protect him because he may or may not be `the chosen one'; prophesized to lead their people to peace when other benders using their powers to do bad, come-a-knockin'.I can't even begin to explain the plot from there, because it was all over the place, and to be quite honest, I lost interest within the first 15 minutes. From what I could gather, at one point it was pretty clear, but then quickly becomes murky with useless added elements. Out of left field Sokka begins a romance with a princess, then she is somehow a magic fish, and that kid we all loved in Slumdog Millionaire (Dev Patel) comes into play, and tries to beat up our heroes to impress his daddy (Cliff Curtis) who is someone of great importance to the story. And the Slumdog kid's uncle is also evil, and trying to create friction between the father and son.The acting is sometimes good, but is mostly bad. I don't blame any of the actors however, what with the pitiful dialogue they were given to work with. I can see how this flick will be fun for a certain age group of kids, but it's not for me.Please tell me the cartoon it's based on is more appealing than this. And God help us, based on the end, there will be at least another installment to follow this segment of dread. I'll leave you with saying that, once upon a time... M. Night Shyamalan used to be a great story teller.

reviewText: The previews/trailers on TV made THE LAST AIRBENDER look great--and M. Night Shyamalan's big name and previous work raised my family's expectations very high.Ten minutes into this film, we agreed that the dialogue was VERY poor. We speculated that it was perhaps a film aimed at ten-year-olds. Fifteen minutes into it, one of us suggested that the script had actually been written BY ten-year-olds. Thereafter, we made a game of watching it: whenever anything outrageously funny occurred (unintentionally funny, of course), we would pause the film to make fun of it--and sometimes replay the scene once or twice.The story is a jumble of elements "borrowed" from a dozen or more better fantasy and martial arts films. The plot premise is rather childish, the continuity is poor and illogical, and the dialogue is stilted some moments and slangy-modern other moments--with the whole film being merely a set-up for . . . a sequel.The acting is uneven--ranging from "F" quality up to the "C" range. Even the more experienced and skilled cast members have to cope with  poor writing and stereotyped characters. Sadly, there is not even one person in this film that we can really care about, favorably or unfavorably.The special effects are mostly a huge disappointment--for about 4 minutes near the end, they approach the quality of those in CROUCHING TIGER, HIDDEN DRAGON--but mostly they are boring or just laughable. Most of the battle scenes lack "drive" and "cohesion." They typically involve one-on-one fights, even when fifty or more people are faced off--i.e., two people kick or swing at each other until one of them is knocked down, while everyone else basically stands and waits--then the next couple starts kicking or swinging, etc. etc. etc. Rarely is there any sense of a real group battle taking place, such as we get in films like THE LORD OF THE RINGS and THE GOLDEN COMPASS--or even KUNG FU PANDA.And speaking of THE LORD OF THE RINGS, watching any two minutes of it is at least fifteen times more enjoyable and meaningful than the entire experience of THE LAST AIRBENDER.Among this DVD's "bonus features" are few deleted scenes. Most viewers, after looking at these, will probably wish that many MORE scenes had been deleted.The GOOD news for my family is that we rented it. I would strongly recommend that nobody buy this film without first doing likewise. While it is always possible that you will love this film and want to watch it often--it is very very VERY unlikely.

reviewText: Part of me is heartbroken by the amount of negative criticism "The Last Airbender" received, considering I'm a fan of the original series, and yet I'm not too surprised.  This is a film directed by someonewho thinks humanity will be attacked by pollen, and it's adapting the show's first season into a feature-length plane; to be fair, half of the first season was filler anyway, so the film shouldn't have too much trouble adapting important story elements from Book 1.  Because of prior expectations, I did anticipate some grave prospects like the kid actors being shoddy, having repulsively stupid scenes like when Peter Parker went gothic in "Spider-man 3", or even make a lackluster effort into follow its source material. As it turned out, only one of those prospects were true, but I was otherwise pretty humble with its final product. It's not a very good adaptation, but at least it's a step above "Jonah Hex" and "Dragonball: Evolution".  To go into further details due to my exposure to the cartoon, I'll have to review it in two ways: my normal foolhardy self, and my FANBOY self.I should commend M. Night Shyamalan for trying to be straightforward with the story; I'm not saying it's simple, just straightforward.  It goes through the premise of a world where certain people can manipulate certain elements in four different nations.  The fire nation decided to conquer the world, and only the master of all four elements, The Avatar can stop it, but he vanished for a century until he was discovered by two teens from the southern water tribe.  The Avatar is a young reluctant airbender who hasn't understood his powers, and thus he and the discoverers go on a journey so he can learn to bend them all.  The movie is pretty faithful to the first sesaon, where it ends in the aftermath of the northern water tribe battle, and there isn't a insipid twist in the mix.  I do have to chastise him a bit for starting the film with a boring opening crawl with nothing in the background; it could've been more exciting to show the events that occur in the past instead of just leaving text to be read by the narrator.  Speaking of, the narrator is very obnoxious, from explaining many events that never happened on-screen to detailing what the characters are feeling; yea, because if the two people are staring at each other with love in their eyes, I have to be told they're in love.  The audience isn't that dumb.[FANBOY] OMG, what happened to the original characters?  They changed so much during the movie transition!  Katara is no longer bossy and spunky, she's now happy and mellow and completely boring.  And what happened to her hair-loopies?!  Sokka lost his comic relief trait and the stiffly-performance actor made him sound mopey and pathetic; he had a unique character arc in the series, and this movie trashed it.  The Fire Lord Ozai shouldn't even be in this first act of the story, he was only briefly mentioned in the show's Book 1 and is shown in silhouettes, which the mystery of him makes him a formidable foe.  Iroh and Zhao seems to have their roles switched, as Iroh appear more lean and threatening than Zhao, which should've been the other way around.  The only characters that remain what they originally were are the main protagonist and antagonist, Aang and Zuko; Aang still has that carefree, fun and idealistic attitude about him, and while Zuko had hair this early in the story, the actor manage to keep the basic structures of his character, which are hot-tempered and assertive.  BTW, why are their names pronounced so differently? [/FANBOY]"The Last Airbender" has a serious emphasis on exposition.  Put aside the analytical narrator, the characters themselves revolve around explaining what they're suppose to do, who they are, and what path they should follow, nevermind just having a chat for fun.  I don't mind a little guidance to the plot, but such expository can be arbitrary at times.  One unorthodox scene has Zuko asking some random kid to explain how the antagonist had a scar on his face and why he was exiled from his nation; why didn't Zuko explain this himself and why wasn't this backstory shown earlier when Zhao confronted Zuko about his exile, I was baffled.  Even after putting much time in explaining things, it doesn't explain enough.  There are a lot plot holes in this movie that would irritate 100-year-old wheelchair bound psychopaths with a taste for pizza rolls.  It didn't explain how Aang and his large pet Appa were frozen in ice for a century, how Zuko found out that Aang was captured by Zhao at one point, how Aang found out about the secret temple needed to learn about his legacy, or how Zhao discovered the secret scrolls needed to destroy the plot device later in the film.[FANBOY]  Of course, I knew exactly why since I saw the first season more than twice, but what about the audience who never saw the cartoon?  Those are issues that can't be ignored.  I'm annoyed by how the film downplayed certain elements from the show.  It downplayed the romance between Aang and Katara (darn it, I want my Kataang!), it downplayed Princess Yue which makes her final moment lacking the impact it originally had, and it even downplayed the Avatar State.  The Avatar State was a powerful form for Aang, and he didn't want to use it because of how dangerous and uncontrollable it is, which became an ongoing crisis which also developed his character; in this movie, he only used it once to make a large tidal wave that does nothing.  Sadly, the movie also downplayed its humor.  It's a serious movie, TOO serious; the cartoon does have its dramatic elements, but it's always in high spirits, being funny as well as being adventurous.  Taking away the fun of the show makes the characters and their situations unfulfilling for this movie. [/FANBOY]Now that I think about it, the plot of "The Last Airbender" is incredibly bare.  It could've been better as a 2 1/2 hour movie instead of 90 minutes, that way most of the plot holes would be resolved and more time would help develop the characters.  But as it is, the film's a byproduct of the director knowing the people love the source material, but he doesn't seem to know WHY they do: it's an underwhelming treatment for the show's fans and a rushed, convoluted movie for non-fans; I could see why both sides wanted to burn this to the ground.I still enjoy it for its technical achievements.  The special effects were well-done, the fight scenes were pretty sweet...except for the stupid Earthbending scene ("You're standing in dirt!"), and it had some decent performances; the actor playing Sokka was the weakest in the cast, but Noah Ringer did a fine job as Aang and so is Dev Patel as Zuko.  The music was the only technical aspect I didn't like, it's about as westernized as the actors playing the characters; could've been better with exotic Asian instruments.  For all it's faults, I'm one of the few who's willing to give the film a pass.[Reviewer's View: possible sequels]Considering how critically panned it is and the underwhelming box-office sales, it's all but guaranteed that there's not going to be a sequel.  But what if there is?  In fact, just the thought of it actually scares me.  Unlike the first season, EVERY EPISODE OF SEASON TWO IS IMPORTANT!  Even a 2 1/2 hour movie wouldn't cover it without severely cutting important sub-plots; heck, the first film already removed one sub-plot about a rebel kid, which would appear in the next act.  And since the first movie is devoid of comedy, I'm pretty sure the same mood applies to the second film, meaning when the second act introduces the blind character, it would possibly excised the cynical, sarcastic charm about that character; plus, there would be no more funny blind jokes.I can't believe I'm thinking negatively about a sequel that hasn't been greenlighted at this point.

reviewText: No matter how bad M. reviewText: There are good adaptations. There are bad adaptations. And there are adaptations that rip asunder the source material and gleefully devour its corpse.This is one of the last category.I might have been able to still enjoy "The Last Airbender" if it had merely had special effects, a horrible script and actors with the charisma of a plank. But director M. Night Shyamalan gets EVERYTHING ELSE wrong too, from the character motivations to bending.Southern Water Tribe girl Katara and her brother Sokka stumble across a glowing glacier, and find a young Airbender boy inside. Since all the other Airbenders are dead, Katara figures out that Aang is the Avatar -- the master of all four elements, and the only person in the world who can defeat the powerful Fire Nation.However, the Fire Nation has already found him, in the form of the disgraced Prince Zuko (Dev Patel). Aang, Sokka and Katara set out on a perilous voyage to the North Pole to find a waterbending master. But the malevolent Admiral Zhao -- Zuko's nemesis -- is approaching the North Pole with the Fire Nation navy, with a plan that may destroy them all.M. Night Shyamalan had a golden opportunity with "The Last Airbender" -- the original cartoon was intelligent, funny, complex and filled with brilliant martial-arts and strong philosophical overtones. So instead he decided to make a movie with NONE of that -- a witless, humorless, simplistic stumbling behemoth of a film.The culture, the characters, the climactic battle, the bending, the acting, the action sequences, and even the pronunciation of the names... EVERYTHING IS WRONG. WRONG, WRONG, WRONG. But if I listed everything wrong with the movie, this review would be the size of a novel.Even from an objective perspective, this movie is a disaster. Shyamalan clearly has no idea how to write an action movie, blasting through incoherent fight scenes in one long pan. The story feels painfully repetitive (how many times is Aang going to be captured?!) and the script is horrendously pompous, humorless and rushed ("We have to show them that we believe in our beliefs as much as they believe in theirs" -- WHAT? You're not trying to SAVE THE WORLD?).Also, there are gaping plot holes that a three-year-old can spot. So the Fire Nation imprisons Earthbenders, who manipulate rocks and soil... in a friggin' MINE. And the pseudo-Buddhist Aang apparently has no problem with COLD-BLOODEDLY KILLING HUNDREDS OF PEOPLE. Was Shyamalan mocking us with how bad he could make this, or did he just not care?I will give Dev Patel credit -- even though his Zuko's main source of angst seems to be a mild case of eczema, he does put a lot of passion and intensity into the role.Sadly, the same cannot be said of the other actors. Aang is wooden and mopey, Katara is weepy and inept, and Sokka comes across as a ticking time bomb. Even the talented Shaun Toub plays the horrendously-written role of Iroh with an air of boredom -- he always looks like he's thinking, "Okay, when do I get paid?" Only Aasif Mandvi seems to be having fun chewing the scenery.M. Night Shyamalan managed something truly impressive in "The Last Airbender" -- he managed to take a funny, well-written, intelligent series and suck out all the humor, cleverness and likability from it.

reviewText: It was not my place to look for logic, sophistication or even common sense in THE LAST AIRBENDER. It is not in my habit to comment much on the films of Shyamalan, though one day of course I'll review them all.After that disclaimer, I have to say I was charmed enough by AIRBENDER to sit through it and enjoy. The young actors are cute and well disciplined; the older ones are impressive considering the film they find themselves serving.In this film we are introduced to "benders"- vaguely Chinese/Tibetan/Norse/Lapp/Eskimo tribes scattered around some mythical world. Each tribe has total power over an element (hence the "bending"): water, earth, air, fire (and I guess metal was missing). The young water-bender is a charming girl who struck me as a Lapp, and her lovely older brother is very funny.Into this frozen land where they live (was that Greenland?) comes the last air-bender, a goofy little kid who looks like a Shao-lin priest. I'll say right now, I am utterly sick of true history being pillaged then misrepresented by the movies. But then, there is my original disclaimer so I'll leave it at that.A war of elements is at hand, and the last air-bender is also The Avatar. Based on the Buddhist tradition's 'messiah', he is supposed to bring balance to the force, oops, wrong movie, something like that anyway.One major pet peeve of mine is this reeling in an audience, only to find that at the end of the film it's half or a third of the way through the whole story. What if something happens, they make no sequel, audiences rebel? What if we suddenly become theater-seat-benders and whack the silver screen out of existence just to teach M. Knight a lesson?As a very decrepit old "fan boy", I can relate to those who are addicted to the books, the tv cartoon and whatever else was ground out of that neo-Disneyesque anime factory. I am no fan of anime, since I sort of grew up on the original anime-type of garbage. I also don't care too much for tv cartoons. (Except SpongeBob, his first couple of seasons are funny.) So I will never understand the immature, rabid criticism or beloved adoration I see directed at this film- or at any other cartoon-to-film adaptation. All I want to know is when will it stop!!Film, to me, is film. It isn't anime, it isn't American cartooning, it isn't a tv show. This film, however, should have been done on tv. Oh wait, it already was. How redundant.Well, this was fun enough, and it tries in a feeble way to teach compassion- I suppose there's a hidden environmental agenda here too. My wife saw this film fresh off the silver screen and she said it was "stupid". Therefore I had to see it.It isn't stupid. It is a Nickelodeon movie, and would have been much more fun to see as-is on television. Shyamalan has nothing better to do I suppose, so there's his direction as a negligible inducement. He does well enough- I can only add that it is worth seeing for the effects and phony-baloney martial arts which still look quite elegant.Just don't try any of their tricks at home (well, splashing bath water is OK).By the way, only in America is "Ang" or "Aang" pronounced "aing" or whatever it is that I see is bugging people. Everywhere on earth where people use ANG/AANG as a name it is pronounced the way it is pronounced in this film. Sorry, AHNG-haters! - you insult Ang (open wide, say AHHHHHHNNNNNNGGGGGG) Lee and expect to get away with that?!

reviewText: Not since Spielberg's "A.I. Artificial Intelligence" in 2001 have I heard such hatred heaped upon a director and his film as with Shyamalan's much anticipated "The Last Airbender".  If the gods seek to destroy those they once called promising, perhaps that is so with Mr. Shyamalan.  The critics, who once called him the next Spielberg, now scorn and dismiss him.  These self-appointed lesser gods, who have never made movies themselves, have the power to destroy those who do.  Their influence over audiences and ticket sales is without doubt, so it is not surprising that Sony invented a phony movie critic called "David Manning" in 2001 to write favorable reviews of its films.  Well, I liked this film, and I have never made a movie, either.Everything I knew, in fact, I learned from the publicity.  I didn't expect the movie to be great, I'd hoped it would be good, but it wasn't as bad as these critics say.  I departed with a hunger to learn more.  As a newbie to the story, though, and I am not the only one, perhaps I should not have had to ferret it out on my own, as I had to do with the puzzle of Spielberg's "A.I."  But I like to do research.After I viewed some episodes on Amazon and learned more, I have become a fan.  The cartoon series, much beloved by its fans, is a good story.  I expect to purchase the DVD sets.  I saw the movie again and enjoyed it much better, though I still had quibbles about it.  There were a few times when I imagined how I might write, direct, frame, or shoot a scene to make it different or more powerful.  For example, in the climactic scene, when Aang reaches deep into his memories and emotions before facing the Fire Nation navy, I would've made his reaction more cathartic, his battle less effortless.  I do that with movies, sometimes.  This is not to say my vision is better or that is the way it should've been done, just what I might have done.  I don't make movies.I liked the premise of the story, which some critics misunderstood, and I liked the visual majesty of it.  It's properly targeted at and safe for kids.  I liked the fantasy world, the martial arts work, and Mr. Shyamalan's vision of it.  It was clean, escapist entertainment.If the dialogue and story changes sound cartoonish, well, a cartoon was its source, right?  I guess some have forgotten the cartoonish dialogue, non sequitur scenes, and sorry acting in "Star Wars".  I guess some expected a word-for-word, scene-for-scene, blow-by-blow replication of the cartoon series first season of 20 episodes.  They got a stripped-down adaptation in 103 minutes that condenses or overlooks a lot.  That is not unusual.  Whenever a film is adapted from another source, such as, a book or play, it's a palimpsest from the original, and there are always changes, compromises.  Those fans and others should get a life.  I agree, though, that 15 to 30 minutes of film time must be missing.  Perhaps they should've planned for more than three movies or filmed the trilogy all at once.  It's too bad Mr. Shyamalan has disappointed some very vocal fans, but there it is--a strategic fault that the directors of "Harry Potter" and "The Lord of the Rings" were cognizant to avoid.The cast is ok and so is their understated acting, considering the source.  Noah Ringer is the martial arts prodigy hired to play Aang, the character he strongly resembles, the reincarnation of the avatar, the spiritual savior who can control all the elements to keep them in balance.  I don't like to discuss child actors.  But think about it: a $150M movie rests on the shoulders of an inexperienced 12 year old.  He is not the first child actor to have to learn his acting craft on-the-job.  So, cut the kid some slack, folks.  Noah has his chops now.  We felt he was very good, some of his martial arts were graceful, even beautiful to watch, self-possessed and controlled, and we hope he will reprise his role if sequels are made.Some think Mr. Shyamalan has ruined the film and his career.  I don't think so.  As a person of color, too, I found no issue or challenge with it.  The audience applauded after both showings that I saw.  However, I wonder if Nickelodeon, who hoped the property would become their "Harry Potter", agrees.To date, I have seen "The Last Airbender" three times.  I expect to see it again tomorrow.  I like the film enough to give it a fair and just rating.  To borrow from Admiral Farragut, "Damn the critics!  Full steam ahead!"  When Kubrick's famous film, "2001", opened in 1968, the critics savagely dismissed it and its director; so, never mind them.  I conclude by echoing one of the other commentators here.  Thank you, Mr. Shyamalan, for making this film, but please make the sequels great.

reviewText: I have read a rew hundred reviews on this movie, some people claiming its great, the majority saying its total crap. While I am a devoted fan to the television series, it wasn't necessarily the bastardization of the storyline that made me dislike this movie. I can fully understand why the director might have found it difficult to condense the entire first volume of the anime into one single film. Actually, it was the acting and the style in which the movie was filmed that I found myself hating the most.First off, the 'Ung' sound of Aang's name was just something I could not get over. Every time I heard it, I had to remind myself that the actors were referring to a person and not just making some kind of grunting sound.Second, would it have been so difficult for the director to find a seasoned actor with martial arts training to play Aang. Every time that kid talked, it was like watching the very first harry potter movie (you know, when they were barely tweens and still learning how to act).Third, why did the camera repeatedly do close-ups. I had heard of this from a friend, but until I watched the movie I didn't really understand what they meant. Bascially, when one of the characters give one of their many speeches, the camera moves so close that all you see if the very middle of their face. Sometimes even the chin and top-most part of their forehead is off screen. I'm sorry, but I can't watch a movie where half the time the camera is doing close-ups. By the end of the movie I was yelling for the cameraman to LAY OFF THE ZOOM.I also agree with a lot of other reviews on this website, I would look forward to someone else creating a worthy adaptation of the television show. Directors are doing remakes and adaptations all the time from foreign films and books, it just seems disappointing that the director didn't take notes on previous attempts. Heck, even the simpsons movies found a way to be decent. Maybe the director should have done a continuation of the series, used his own creativity. Like the title of the review says, I think this film is evidence that the director should go back to film school and relearn the basics.
summary: Maybe a Return to Film School is Needed?

I mean the changes made by the Director are all for the worse, the fight scenes are uninteresting and not exciting even if some of the effects are ok, the acting is wooden (though most of the blame goes again to the script), and any fun and depth the cartoon had was stripped away. The movie is too serious but never even manages to feel epic or emotional, the script is awful. But again I feel it all gets magnified by how rushed everything is. So it is a amazingly unbelievable that the home video version lacks any extended cut, so no redemption for this poor excuse of adaptation. I do hope they make more of these movies, the next 2 books in the cartoon are much better, I just hope they let someone else do it. I do not hate the director, some of his stuff I like, some I do not, but in this instance I feel like it is my obligation like community service or the day's good deed to warn you, this is a bad movie. To be fair I am sure kids will still like it but again the script is too serious to even make it a good children's movie.

reviewText: This movie had so, so much potential to be good. Unfortunately, it fails not only to live up to the expectations of fans of the series, but also fails to stand on its own as a standalone film. I actually rather like M. Night Shymalan's movies, even the ones that most people hated like "Lady in the Water" and "The Village". From beginning to end, however, this movie was just plain awful.My biggest problem with this movie is simply that Mr. Shyamalan took an entire season of a very well fleshed-out and developed series, set in a world that doesn't work quite like the real one, with what are very complicated cultural and political structures going on, and tried to jam it into less than two hours of time. The result is film with a barely-coherent story, dialogue that is composed almost entirely of exposition, and not enough time spent with any of the characters to care what happens to them. Had I not seen the series this movie was based upon, this movie would have seemed like a string of completely unrelated events. Having seen the series and being a fan, it was painful to see vibrant and well-developed characters reduced to blank-stared, in-story narrators.Even the visual effects and action scenes fell short for me. In an attempt to showcase the element-bending effects, the battle scenes featured heavy use of slow-motion. Rather than make the bending more impressive, it just sucked every last bit of excitement out of the action. A movie with nature-element superpowers and lots of nifty martial-arts type moves should not come off feeling sluggish. I wonder how much time would have been shaved off from the overall length of the film had they run the battles at normal speed.The acting was painful, although I'm not sure I can fault the actors. When most of your dialogue is narration, there isn't much you can do with that. The only character that didn't come off as awkward and stilted in his delivery was Dev Patel as Prince Zuko. Zuko was the only character that really got any attention in the script to his background or personality. Unfortunately, one decently-portrayed character had no chance of salvaging this disaster of a movie.I really can look past the usual complaints about this movie regarding casting the main protagonists as Caucasian, while casting Fire Nation antagonists as primarily actors with Indian or Middle-Eastern appearances (I expect that predictable sort of shennanigans from Hollywood, really), and I don't care about the changes in name pronunciations (although I don't think the argument that "that would be the proper pronunciation in most Asian languages" is particularly convincing considering that in this adaptation the characters whose names were affected are decidedly not Asian).For me, this movie failed in story, in dialogue, in pace, and in visuals. As many others have said, check out the animated series, and let's all try to forget that this movie ever happened.

reviewText: I loved the show and this is the movie I've been looking forward to more than any other.  In the end, it is a huge disappointment but it did have some small redeeming qualities, but not enough of them.  I'll start with what I liked:1) Sound Track.  I usually don't point this out, but I was actually digging on the sound track of the show, all except for one scene (the music built up but nothing happened on the screen).2) Added plot elements.  They added a few plot elements, some I liked and some I didn't.  The one I liked was that the movie seemed to focus on building a balance throughout the world instead of, "I'm the Avatar so I'm just going to destroy what gets in my way," like what the show seemed to say.  I liked it, it added a little bit of depth to the roll of the Avatar.3) Special Effects.  I especially loved the special effects of the water and the fire.  The air and the earth bending effects sometimes came across as silly.But there were too many negatives:1) Too short.  The show was several hours long in the first book but this movie was less than two hours.  I think the movie would have been a lot more decent if Shyamalan had put more into character development, relationship building, and story.  Unfortunately, all he could cram into roughly 105 minutes where all the action scenes, which is not why Avatar was so beloved.  It wouldn't have cost him much more to add the character development and it is so unfortunate that he took a skip on it.2) Added plot elements. So, Aang is not allowed to have a family since he is the Avatar.  What?  Why was this added into the movie?  In the show other Avatars were shown with family.  In fact, since he is the last airbender he really SHOULD create a family so that the Airbender Nomads can be re-formed.  Was this something that Shyamalan had planned on revisiting in the future?  For now, I just don't get it.3) 3D.  I knew I wasn't going to like the 3D as soon as I had heard it was done post-production.  I should have followed my instinct and just caught the 2D version.  The 3D version is dark with very little life in the colors.  In fact, many scenes I removed the glasses just so I could enjoy the (blurry) scenes that were filmed.  If Shyamalan continues making this in 3D, I hope he shoots it in 3D instead of doing it afterward.4) No character development and relationship building.  A real shame as this is what made the show so wonderful.  But Aang doesn't even seem to get along with Katara and Sokka.  In fact, if I hadn't seen the show, I think I would wonder why two kids where helping out the Avatar to begin with, or why the Avatar would even have them along.5) Names.  I don't know why, but many of the names were re-pronounced for the movie, often times replacing hard vowels with soft ones.  Aang sounded more like Ung.  They didn't even say the word Avatar right.  Was this a copyright issue?  I can't figure out why this happened.6) Poor editing.  This is a roller-coaster of a ride as locations and plot lines seemed to be thrown at us at 100 miles per hour.  This is not a compliment.  If I hadn't seen the show I know I wouldn't be able to keep up.  Again, transitions could have been helped along with the character and even plot building.In the end, it is more bad than good.  It is a poorly executed movie and I expected more from Shyamalan.  If you where a fan of the show I'd suggest you wait until it comes out as a rental... a Netflix rental at that.  If you didn't watch the show I would avoid this movie like the plague.  In fact, do yourself a favor and watch the show.  The special effects weren't fantastic but everything else is FANTASTIC!No matter what, I'd suggest skipping on the 3D version.  I wish I had.
summary: The Biggest Letdown of the Year

reviewText: In brief:  This is a deeply moving, spiritual fantasy film that differs in some ways from the cartoon series on which it's based. Understand going in that it's a condensed version of 20 episodes and, as such, there were changes to be made.  Any rational person could see that would be necessary.  Even the creators of this series, who mixed both Western and Eastern story-telling elements, knew and approved of these changes. Many of these changes are for the better and deepen the flow, reality and, ultimately, the heart of the film. If you re-watch the first season you can see where M. Night took the heart of the episodes and crafted an even better and emotion-filled core and ending for this series.Many of those who rallied against this film fall into one major category - obsessed fan-boys with no sense of perspective.  They are a heartless bunch. Many of them even got tied up in the race of the characters - characters voiced by white actors in the cartoon, a cartoon which was created by two white dudes, and animated in style that mixes both Eastern and Western animation styles. This is a fantasy world people!  And even so,  M. Night took the most inclusive approach possible and said, hey let's show as many races as we can - we can have Asians, Whites, Blacks and Indians in this fantasy world.  But no. The fanboys got offended and started an internet-based political movement against this film: the so-called race-bending controversy.  In doing so, these fanboys became the very thing they accused the filmmakers being: flat-out racists. Racism is when you don't accept someone for the color of their skin.  They couldn't accept Indian firebenders or white waterbenders.  Who are the real racists here?  All told, they've shown themselves to be as a whole a group of heartless, nit-picking navel-gazers, lacking the souls necessary to really appreciate this great film. They've flooded the internet with hate.  They won't stop.  Even now, months after the film's release, they post on message-boards (and here on Amazon) just to tell you how much they hate it. Who does that?  They don't want to see a sequel - by any means necessary.I for one want a sequel - badly.  The film made over $315 million world-wide.  Apparently, I'm not the only one who wants a sequel.I love the show and I love this movie. Both have a place in my heart. I guess I root for the underdog and when so many critics rag on a film you have to take a step back and wonder what's really going on.  This film made over $315 million worldwide, so there's hope for a sequel. I for one don't really get all of the hate.  What film did the critics see? It seems to me like there was a studio-driven campaign against this movie to fail. Maybe one lead by FOX who put out the other Avatar in name? There was a massive media blitz against this film. Can you think of any other film with so much hate directed against it?  Think about that for a moment. Can you?All of the so-called super-fans of the TV show need to relax. There is no way that they could show all of the countless characters and locations that are in season one in one movie. Think of all the stuff that gets cut of of a Harry Potter novel for just one film - 2 films for one book doesn't make it twice as good. Realistically, how many movies should they have made just about season one?  Even if you did two for season one, you'd have no story arc.  It wouldn't have been as satisfying.  The movie and main character had a great emotional arc, in my opinion.  This was also a more thoughtful film than critics would have you believe.  I bought it on DVD.  I have all of the Avatar Season Box sets as well.  Changes were made for the sake of a movie, but overall it was an enjoyable ride.  Don't listen to the critics.  Judge for yourself.  Stop the hate.Noah Ringer is Aang.  Shaun Toub was amazing as Uncle Iroh.  Devel Patel was terrific as Zuko.  The special effects were great.  The score was beautiful.  The story had great emotion and moved me.  M. Night did a great job.  Bring on Books Two and Three.
summary: Loved it.  Surprisingly good - after all of the hate directed at it.

reviewText: First things first, I'm convinced there is a mixup on my DVD.  I believe the link to the movie and the link to the deleted scenes are flip-flopped.  No way that's the movie.  With that said, here's my review of the "movie."The plot is borderline incomprehensible.  I guess that's the result of condensing a 20-episode series into a 90 minute movie.  In some ways it's like taking the entire contents of my refrigerator and creating a giant smoothie.  After each I want to vomit.  Anyway, two kids are hanging out in the South Pole when they find an iceberg.  Despite the ability to "bend" all elements (including water), the kid inside has been imprisoned, in ice!, for an insignificant period of time.  5318008 or 8675309 years.  I'm not completely sure, and I don't care.  Bada-boom, bada-bing, in walks roughly 200 unconnected, supporting actors/characters, some logorrhea about powers and spirits, enough FX to make Michael Bay moist, and an open-ended finale portending a sequel that, if made, will undoubtedly be used during the torture scenes of anyZero Dark Thirtyfollow-ups.  Let's hope Ebert is right and the "title proves prophetic."Some of the dialogue is so wooden I was convinced Kristen Stewart would make a cameo.  And don't even get me started on the expository nature of nearly every.single.word.  Dora the Explorer provides fewer clues.  The laughable acting and casting certainly doesn't help.  There is no subtlety.  No nuance.  When a character is angry, it's all foot-stomping, furrowed brows, Charlie Chaplin exaggeration - sorry, Charlie - in an effort to explain what the plot and dialogue cannot.  It's kind of like watching a baby cry, not knowing what exactly is wrong, then smelling poop.  Actually, it's almost exactly like that.  To be quite honest, aside from Shaun Toub, the best performance of the film goes to the CGI dragon.  And Dev Patel as a villain?  I've seen more menacing figures on cereal boxes.The only redeeming aspect to this film is the FX.  It's decent when everything else doesn't suck so bad.  To put it simply, if you liked this movie, you are probably M. Night Shyamalan.

reviewText: Where do I even begin?  I just want to let you know that I began watching the Avatar: The Last Airbender cartoon series ever since this film adaptation hit the big screen, and it became my absolute favorite Nickelodeon animated series of all-time.  This is thanks to high-octane action scenes, beautiful animation, creative element bending, charm, heart, humor, top-notch conflict, emotion, lovable characters, and a really thought-provoking story arc that discusses various real-life issues, all of which is ripe for expanding upon in film-making.  THERE WAS NO EXCUSE FOR THIS MOVIE TO BECOME THE COMPLETE ANTITHESIS TO WHAT THE SHOW STANDS FOR!  I mean, what happened to you, M. Night Shyamalan?  Both The Sixth Sense & Unbreakable were really solid thrillers and Signs was fun to watch despite it's faults.  After that, your writing skills deteriorated.  Granted I have yet to see The Village (despite hearing polarizing things about it and plan on updating the review once I see it), but Lady in the Water was an over-glorified bedtime story in disguise as a fantasy film and The Happening can compete with Nightmare on Elm Street 5 & 6 for craziest horror movie ever made.  However, they were the former three of Shyamalan's aforementioned directorial efforts, compared to this.  I used to think The Happening was worse, but after taking into account that it was at least trying as a horror movie and had a few interesting ideas, this became more alienating since it butchered a brilliant cartoon and didn't even try.  It's such a shame because he really was looking forward to making a film adaptation of this show after watching it with his family, as seen in an interview with him and the show's creators in the Season 2 box set, but the action genre was new to him and I heard a rumor that the producers rushed him.  However, I don't know who was truly at fault for this film's tasteless quality.  Like everyone else pointed out, it completely disregarded what made the show so special and instead suffered from a rushed "chess-piece" plot, lifeless direction, lack of character & emotional development, awkward acting (for the most part), sluggish action scenes & bending, the idea of taking a 20-episode season and adapting it into a 108-minute motion picture (resulting in excessive narrations of key plot points), cleaner cinematography than the Star Wars Prequel Trilogy, cheap 3D post-conversion, getting the races of some characters mixed up, their foreign accents changing the pronunciation of certain characters' names, dumb decisions, Princess Yue's hairdo looking like a certain male reproductive system (let's just say), and sheer boredom.  I will admit that the bending effects & sets were decent on a technical level, the re-enactment of the show's opening was promising, Dev Patel, Sahun Toub, & Aasif Mandvi at least tried with what they had to work with, the best action scene was with Aang vs. Zuko in the Northern Water Tribe Village, and the James Newton Howard score was pretty cool, but that's about it.  There was nothing else I liked about it.  At the end of the day, it really is one of the worst movies I have ever seen in my life and a complete train-wreck of a beloved cartoon.  It makes Dragonball Evolution look like The Fugitive by comparison.  I don't want to kick a dead horse, seeing as how everyone ripped it a new one, but please watch the cartoon instead.  You will be a lot happier.  If you want to know more as to why this movie blows rice ball chunks, watch the Nostalgia Critic's review.  Pretty much everything he says, I agree on.  With that said, see you later, and Legend of Korra was a huge, huge improvement over this lame-brained excuse for a movie in execution.
